3-7-62 Page 3
With this kind of preparation competed, the full Board could
then re-convene for an action session to consider every item on its
enlarged agenda. There should, by then, be topics submitted by com¬
mittee chairmen through their appointing authority, the President;
by the NAEB officers; and by the Board itself. Some of the topics
could be disposed of on their own simple merit, as of little relevance
to other NAEB activities. Others would likely receive a more judi¬
cious appraisal in light of how they would affect other goals and
objectives of the organization.
I would fully expect the referral of quite a few items to the
appropriate NAEB committees for further study and recommendation to
the Board.
I submit these suggestions seriously, but not presumptuously, as
one way we might attack the task we all agreed to do when we allowed
ourselves to be elected to membership on the Board. I hope they*re
received in the way they*re intended -- as a simple tune-up to a
basically sound, well-designed and reliable old engine.
If you*ve managed to read this far, many thanks for "hearing me
out."
Sincerely

Ken Kager, Chairman
